711787f-a.text: 532-522 West 24th Street, south side, between Eleventh and Tenth Avenue.  About 1915

711778f-a.text: 24th Street, south side, east from Tenth Avenue.  in the right foreground may be seen the original London Terrace, a row of cottages and apartment houses built in 1845 by Bishop Clement C. Moore, author of "The Night Before Christmas".  These houses were modeled on similar structures popular in London at the the time, and for many years constituted a very fashionable address.  They were demolished in 1929 and 1930, and replaced by a series of large modern apartment houses which retain the name London Terrace.  About 1927.  Price Studios, Inc.

710499f-a.text:
Tenth Avenue, east side, north from 24th Street.
March 12, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

711782f-a.text:
433 to 463 West 24th Street at N.E. corner of Tenth Avenue, and
east to middle of block, seen from 23rd Street across the clearing where the old London Terrace houses have been pulled down and the
new London Terrace buildings will rise.
September 29, 1929

P. L. Sperr

711779f-a.text:
24th Street, south side, east from Tenth Avenue. At the right is the row of houses which constituted the 24th Street front of the original London Terrace, built in 1845 by Bishop Clement C. Moore. They will be torn down in 1929 and 1930 to be replaced by large modern buildings.
March 12, 1929.
P.L. Sperr.

710501f-b.text:
(1)
Tenth Avenue at N.E. corner of 24th Street, showing boys on horseback riding ahead of a freight train. Under an old New York statute, never repealed, every surface train must be preceded by one or more horseback riders, to give warning. These riders are known as "Eleventh Avenue cowboys".
March 12, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #4604
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  r N  NhP  i R208S  1
(2)
The same, seen across the wreckage of old London Terrace.
May 31, 1930.
L. Sperr.
